Reasons for Federalism
3. Reasons for Federalism

Many arguments for federalism have traditionally been put in terms of
promoting various forms of liberty in the form of non-domination,
immunity or enhanced opportunity sets (Elazar 1987a). When considering
reasons offered in the literature for federal political orders, many
appear to be in favor of decentralization without requiring
constitutional entrenchment of split authority. Two sets of arguments
can be distinguished: Arguments favoring federal orders compared with
secession and completely independent sovereign states; and arguments
supporting federal arrangements rather than a (further) centralized
unitary state. They occur in different forms and from different
starting points, in defense of ‘coming together’
federalism, and in favor of ‘holding together’
federalism.
